content.webTitle: The Handmaid's Tale recap: episode seven – hope reigns

fields.headline: The Handmaid's Tale recap: episode seven – hope reigns
fields.bodyText: Spoiler alert: this recap is for people watching The Handmaid’s Tale on Channel 4 in the UK. Please do not add spoilers from later episodes. This felt like exactly the right time for a full flashback episode. Obviously anyone who has read the book knows there are still interesting developments to come back at the Waterford residence. But after last week’s revelation about Luke, I’m glad we actually get to see his journey since that fateful ambush in the first episode. This is the handmaid’s tale and hers alone, but the wife’s tale (last week) and the husband’s this week are welcome embellishments. When we first left Luke at the side of the road, cowering by the family’s crashed Volvo, we followed June and Hannah into the woods. This week we see Luke’s valiant one-man resistance and his The Fugitive-style escape from the back of that crashed ambulance. In the quiet chaos following the vehicle’s spectacular roll down the river bank, Luke takes what he needs, stuffs his bag full of pain relief and one of the guardian’s guns and flees. Slowly. The unbearable tension of suppressed rage, hidden from view, is replaced this week by the unbearable tension that ensues when the suppressed break cover and run. Both are equally hard to watch, but I found myself missing the muted turquoises and creams of the Waterford’s house. This isn’t me saying that the Nazis ran a really efficient train service; I have just grown to admire the order and colour coordination of the Gilead architects. They’re fascists, but tasteful ones. Back in the time before (which we now know is three years prior to the present-day action), Luke and Hannah flee with their drugged daughter – Benadryl antihistamine to ensure she doesn’t give them away – helped by a man who will later pay for his complicity with his life. Lying on the abandoned kitchen floor after his escape, a wounded Luke is rudely awoken by some angry women in beanies . Once they’ve established he’s only wearing the a guardian’s jacket and is really on their side, Luke is scooped up and given medical treatment. He has found salvation, or rather, it has found him. Before you know it, he’s living in Canada, seemingly close to one of the women, Zoe, he met in the van and free of Gilead. For the time being anyway. When Luke insists that he must head back to Boston to find his family, one beanie woman (sadly also RIP by episode’s end) shows Luke inside a nearby church in which the rafters are hung with dead bodies of those who tried to rebel. He gags on the smell and agrees that perhaps he should go to Canada with them to regroup and get clear of the danger. In present-day Toronto, we finally see Luke heading for the official-looking building where he will receive the never-hoped-for message from June, hastily scribbled and handed over before the Mexicans left the Waterford house that morning. Luke walks down a municipal corridor lined with posters of the missing, hundreds of them. An official invites him into an oak-panelled meeting room and hands him an envelope pertaining to one June Osbourne. His face says he’s expecting confirmation of her death but the envelope contains that same scrap of note paper she held at the end of last week’s episode. The thought of even that connection between them is thrilling considering the intervening years. In a direct mirror of last week’s ending, the camera homes in on Luke’s face, the tears coming as it sinks in. She’s alive. He is overcome. In the most judicial edit of the episode, we cut back to Offred sitting in profile in her room, looking more like June than ever despite the handmaid cowl and smock. She says in her head, “I love you. Save Hannah” and I am a mess of parental blubbering. If you aren’t rooting for this little family by now, you’re a lump of sentient clay or Donald Trump or both. To the sound of Nothing’s Gonna Hurt You Baby by Cigarettes After Sex we leave Luke and June locked into each other, despite the distance. Hope reigns. Blessed be the fruit. May the Lord open. Under his eye • Finding his daughter’s shoe in the forest, Luke clings to it desperately, impotent with fury, unable to save his people. It’s too awful. • The ruined town where an injured Luke hides out is covered in graffiti telling us what has already happened here. “Gender traitor” slogans are sprayed on walls and doors. Everything is smashed. The initial push to seize power has been brutal. • When Luke calls Offred “June-bug” in the trunk of the car, it’s shattering, knowing this break for freedom will fail. Their relationship is perfectly foregrounded so that closing shot of Luke has full impact. • Luke’s “Who are you guys?” to the people in the van is met with a grinned, “Two straights, a gay and a nun,” from the kind-looking man in thick-rimmed glasses. God, I was glad of the humour by this point. • I don’t know if I can take another series of this tense awfulness but also, I can’t bear for it to end in just three more instalments. I need June and Luke to find each other again, but I will riot if episode 10 ends with this. Conflicted isn’t the word.
